channel.title: Computer Shutting Down when Gaming
channel.description:
Turned on Crysis 2, set graphics mode to Hardcore just to see it. Not the steadiest framerate (obvious for my specs) and after about two minutes my computer turned off. MOBO light was still on, but power button would not turn the computer on. Turning my PSU off and on didn't help. After about a minute I was able to restart. This made me think it might be overheating, but I'll provide temps later. I played it again, but with graphics mode on Advanced. I got to play for maybe 30 minutes and it did the same thing. This time, after getting past GRUB into Windows, the login screen was flickering. It was turning on and off consistently about four times a second. This was not happening during POST or GRUB, only starting at the login screen. I restarted, and the same thing happened. Although this time, it stopped a little bit after I logged in. I'm wondering if my PSU is not enough anymore, or if I'm overheating.
My Specs: ASUS P5KPL-CM Intel C2E QX6850 @ 3.00GHz 2 x 2GB DDR2 EVGA NVIDIA GTX 570 HD SC PSU 630W
I recently upgraded the GTX 570 from a GeForce 9800 GTX.
I have everything stock cooled and not overclocked. Using EVGA Precision, I have manually set my card to a fan speed of 65% (max was 85%). As far as I can tell, nothing is overheating. Using SpeedFan, it says that my CPU is a little too hot at 55C, but my CORE0 and CORE1 are really low at 30C. I also can't manually control my CPU fan. At idle, here are my temps:
SYSTIN: 43C CPUTIN: 56C AUXTIN: 65C CORE0: 50C CORE1: 50C CORE2: 46C CORE3: 49C CORE0 (from SpeedFan): 30C CORE1 (from SpeedFan): 30C HD0: 39C HD1: 41C GPU: 48C
I do not have the temps of me playing Crisis 2 because I wasn't checking them. I am about to do that now though.

item.title: Computer Shutting Down when Gaming
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Got the PSU in and installed it. I successfully played 2 complete missions on BFBC2 without a stutter. Before, I couldn’t even get halfway through one. Highest temp recorded was 75C on CPU0.

Nothing in my BIOS or BIOS manual about temp shutoffs, so I don’t even think it has that feature.

I’m going to consider this fixed by the new PSU.

Read full topic

item.title: Computer Shutting Down when Gaming
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

I have a 6 year old 650W PSU powering 4x mechanical drives, 4 sticks of ram (8gb), an nvidia GTX 460 with a core overclock of 810mhz, several hundred case fans (mostly just molex->molex with a fan in the middle) and i’ve never had any power problems

Read full topic

item.title: Computer Shutting Down when Gaming
item.dc:creator: @Mr.Chris Mr.Chris
item.description:
@Mr.Chris wrote:

I used to have this problem when playing games, and it came down to the computer overheating, but looking at the bios the temperature shutdown values were pretty low, so just increased them up and never had a problem.

Read full topic

item.title: Computer Shutting Down when Gaming
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“sanga282, post:12, topic:418258”]tbf ive got a 650w psu on a GTX 460 gs, and an oc’d i7 @ 3ghz, and 3 sticks of ddr3 1600mhz ram and mine doesnt have those sorts of power issues, you could ave a faulty card my gtx 285 used to do something similar to that and i juts bought a 460 and it never happened again, also i found my temps werent being accurately recorded when the 285 crashed just because it was corrupting before it could save them[/quote]I’ve got a 650w psu on a GTX 580, 3x mechanical drives, 4 sticks amounting up to 8gb, an external sound card that eats a fair bit of power and a all but one usb slot used up.

I’ve never had power issues :S

item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282

did you replace the psu?

my old psu would take a few minutes before providing power if the mains cut out while it was still on, making me believe your issue might be a psu one

Read full topic

item.title: Computer Shutting Down when Gaming
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

I read in another thread about the card that the PSU not feeding it enough could result in problems (shutting down as a big one).

I found someone else’s rig that involved this card and checked out his PSU that he recommended. I went ahead and bought that because mine’s a POS anyways.

I can run the computer 24+ hours without it shutting down. It’s only when I’m doing something involving the card getting used a lot, like gaming.

I touched all the sides of my PC case before doing anything with removing and installing the new card. I also tried not to touch the board of the card at all, only the design on the front.

Starting a VRAM test.

UPDATE: Results = Passed the whole test, no errors.

Changing video mode to 640x480x16…OK
[10/16/2011 9:45:09 AM] Test started for “Primary Display Driver (NVIDIA GeForce GTX 570)”…
Trying 16bpp RGB:565 mode…OK
TEST FAIL (Code: 8876017C)
Trying 16bpp RGB:555 mode…OK
Trying 16bpp BGR:565 mode…NOT SUPPORTED (Code: 80004001)
Trying 32bpp RGB:888 mode…OK
Trying 32bpp BGR:888 mode…NOT SUPPORTED (Code: 80004001)
[10/16/2011 10:16:06 AM] Pass completed (0 errors found).

Read full topic

item.title: Computer Shutting Down when Gaming
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

From what I understand from electronics, it seems that as long as the volts and watts of the PSU is correct, the amps will be correct. Since voltage is constant, and watts is decided by amps times voltage.

But remember that the GPU isn’t the only thing that wants power.

So, if you could run the GPU in power save mode, you might prove or disprove that the PSU is the problem.

PS: You was aware of static electricity when you upgraded the GPU? And is it possible to run a test on the video memory (A friend suggested that it might cause such problems, and it make sense from where you said the problems appeared)

Read full topic

item.title: Computer Shutting Down when Gaming
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Played Battlefield Bad Company 2 for a little while and it shut off. Temps were the same thing. I left the computer alone for 20 minutes and turned it back on. It won’t turn on again unless I reset the power supply. I’m going to install the stable NVIDIA drivers, and upon a restart I will check to see if I can change the shutoff temps.

UPDATE: Starting to think this is a PSU issue. Card says:
GTX 570 PSU Requirement: - Minimum 550W or greater system power supply (with a minimum 12V current rating of 38A)

I’m running this (maybe not exactly this but it is a Xion 630W:
http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16817190017

Doesn’t say anything near 38A. Any recommendations? I don’t know how to tell if it’s getting the correct Amps, or what to look for in a PSU that will supply what I need.

Read full topic

item.title: Computer Shutting Down when Gaming
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

change the bios shutoff temps

Read full topic

item.title: Computer Shutting Down when Gaming
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Screw up how? If I’m correct, the drivers are the same for my previous and current card. That aside, I did upgrade the drivers right after swapping the cards. It’s pushed in all the way and nothing is in the way of it or anything. I’ll give it more testing.

Read full topic

item.title: Computer Shutting Down when Gaming
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

The computer isn’t very hot, I think you need temps on 80-90 before the computer turns off. (My own experience).

Two thing I can think of: The beta driver has errors (It is a beta after all), or you screwed up when upgrading your graphics card.
If not, I have no ideas.

From what I found, the new card uses 80-100 more watts, so the PSU might be a problem.

Read full topic

item.title: Computer Shutting Down when Gaming
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

I’ve only played Crisis 2 and Just Cause 2 since I’ve upgraded the GFX card. The room is pretty cold right now, at 68F. As far as the drivers go, I updated them to the newest beta NVIDIA drivers to play Battlefield 3, but I never got a chance to play that anyway.

I played Just Cause 2 for about ten minutes before quitting, so I’m not sure if it would crash when playing that.

I’m fairly sure it’s showing the correct temps, because EVGA Precision / SpeedFan / CPUID Hardware Monitor all show the same temperatures for each part, aside from individual cores. CPUID shows four cores each around 50C and SpeedFan shows two cores at 30C, but the CPU reading is the same for both.

UPDATE: I’ve been playing since I made this post that I’m updating now and I have some more numbers for you. I guess it’s been around 40 minutes and I didn’t crash, but I’m still not comfortable that I won’t.

Here’s the temps (only these temps changed, everything else stayed within 1-2 degrees of the original post of all the temps):

CPUTIN: Averaged 69C, max was 72C
CORE0: Averaged 65C, max was 69C
CORE1: Averaged 62C, max was 66C
CORE2: Averaged 58C, max was 60C
CORE3: Averaged 60C, max was 63C
GPU: Averaged 59C, max was 64C

The previous crashes were not during any huge firefight, one during an in-game cutscene and one walking down a hallway. The max temps were only seen once, other than that it was consistently at the average temps.

Read full topic

item.title: Computer Shutting Down when Gaming
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

Are you sure it shows correct temperatures?
Would sitting in a colder room do any good? (Or sitting near a open window).

Does this only happen when playing Crysis?

Try updating your drivers, and let you PC rest a bit. (Hardware can cause temporary problems that disappear after some time off)

Read full topic

item.title: Computer Shutting Down when Gaming
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Turned on Crysis 2, set graphics mode to Hardcore just to see it. Not the steadiest framerate (obvious for my specs) and after about two minutes my computer turned off. MOBO light was still on, but power button would not turn the computer on. Turning my PSU off and on didn’t help. After about a minute I was able to restart. ASUS P5KPL-CM
Intel C2E QX6850 @ 3.00GHz
2 x 2GB DDR2
EVGA NVIDIA GTX 570 HD SC
PSU 630W

SYSTIN: 43C

AUXTIN: 65C

CORE2: 46C
